conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions—I'm Student_A and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m excited about the academic environment and would strongly commit if admitted. I would be grateful for your consideration and am ready to accept immediately if offered a spot.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top true choice, so I should apply immediately. However, School_B’s priority list ranks me last, meaning acceptance is unlikely if higher-priority students apply. Still, applying now is my best shot at my #1 before the seat is taken; if rejected, I can move quickly to School_C next round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_B. After reviewing applications in this round and given our limited available seat, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your effort and wish you the very best in the remainder of the process.

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority ranking is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I received APPLY messages from Student_A and Student_C. Between them, Student_C is ranked higher than Student_A on my list. With quota 1, accepting Student_A now would prevent me from matching with Student_C (or potentially even higher-ranked students like E or B if they apply later). Therefore, to maximize my outcome on my true priority list, I should reject Student_A at this time.

conversation.message: Dear School_B admissions team, I’m Student_C and I’m formally applying to School_B as my first choice. Your program is the best fit for my goals, and if admitted I’m ready to commit and enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: I should start by applying to my top choice, School_B. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_E and Student_B). Applying immediately maximizes my chance before seats fill, and even if Student_B applies, there is still a possibility they go to School_A (their top choice), leaving me as the next preferred candidate at School_B if Student_E chooses another school. So I will make a direct, committed application emphasizing fit and readiness to enroll.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_B. Given our single available seat and the highly competitive pool in this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your effort and wish you the very best in the rest of the process.

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority is E > B > C > D > A, with one seat. In this round I have applications from A and C; C is ranked higher than A, so if I must choose between these two now, accepting C is better. However, Student_E (my top choice) and Student_B (my second choice) have not yet applied this round; both have School_B as a non-first choice but still relatively high (E ranks B last; B ranks B second), so there is some chance they may apply later. The protocol forces an accept/reject on an [APPLY] message (no holding). Given the objective to match as high as possible on my priority list, rejecting C now preserves the possibility of matching with E or B later; if they never apply, I risk ending unmatched or matching with a lower-priority student later. Since C is still my 3rd choice and a strong option, but the upside of waiting for E/B is significant with only one seat, I will reject C in round 1 to keep the seat open for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_D. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m very interested in joining your program. I value a strong academic environment and would be excited to contribute positively to the school community. I would like to formally apply for your available seat this round.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but School_B’s priority list ranks me 4th, behind Student_E, Student_B, and Student_C, so applying immediately is risky if higher-priority students apply. School_C is my 2nd choice and ranks me 3rd, behind only Student_B and Student_C, giving me a stronger chance to secure a high-preference match early. Therefore I will apply to School_C in round 1 to maximize the probability of a top-2 outcome.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for your strong interest in School_C. After reviewing applications received this round, we are not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: School_C has quota 1 and received APPLY from Student_D, Student_B, and Student_E. My true priority ranking is B > C > D > E > A, so Student_D is only my 3rd choice among acceptable students, while Student_B (1st) is available and has applied this round. Since I can directly accept Student_B now, accepting Student_D would block a higher-priority match. Therefore I should reject Student_D in order to preserve the seat for Student_B.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your community. I would like to formally apply and would be ready to commit if accepted. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, but I am low in School_A's priority (4th), so an early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. At School_C, I am ranked #1 in their priority list, and School_C is still high on my true preferences (#3). Securing School_C quickly with an [APPLY] maximizes my chance of matching to a high-ranked option rather than risking being pushed down later.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and your strong interest in School_C. After reviewing this round’s applications, we are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. We look forward to welcoming you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: School_C has quota 1 and received APPLY from Students B, D, and E. On School_C’s true priority list, Student_B is ranked #1, Student_D #3, Student_E #4. Since Student_B is the highest-priority candidate available and has applied with willingness to commit, accepting now secures the best possible match for School_C; no benefit in waiting because no student outranks B on our list.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions—I'm Student_E and I’m formally applying because School_C is my first choice. I’m especially drawn to School_C’s academic rigor and would be excited to contribute through consistent effort, collaboration, and strong classroom engagement. If admitted, I will accept and commit to enrolling. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_C. Although School_C ranks me 4th, applying now is still best because I most want this school and early acceptance is possible if higher-priority students apply elsewhere. I will make a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and motivation.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing why School_C is your first choice. We truly appreciate your strong interest.

At this time, we are unable to offer you admission because our available seat has already been filled this round.

We wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E applied, but School_C’s remaining quota is 0 and we are already matched with Student_B (our top priority). Per rules, with quota 0 we must reject any APPLY regardless of Student_E’s interest or ranking (Student_E is 4th on our true priority list). Maintain the existing match and send a polite rejection noting capacity is full.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_C and I’m writing to formally apply to School_D. I’m very interested in your program and believe it fits my academic goals and learning style well. If offered admission, I’m prepared to accept promptly and enroll.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_C
conversation.thought: My top choice School_B already rejected me, likely holding the single seat for higher-priority applicants. From the remaining unmatched schools, School_A ranks last on my true list, while School_D and School_E are mid-tier. Given priorities, School_D ranks me 3rd (after Student_D and Student_A), which gives me a plausible chance if those students go elsewhere. I will apply to School_D now to secure a strong option before seats fill.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application to School_D and for your thoughtful interest in our program. After review, we are pleased to offer you admission.

Please confirm your intent to enroll so we can finalize your placement.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: School_D’s true priority ranks Student_C (3rd) below Student_D and Student_A, but above Student_E and Student_B. In this round, only Student_C and Student_E applied; between them, Student_C is higher priority. There is no current offer from Student_D or Student_A, and holding out risks ending up with a lower-priority match (Student_E) or remaining unmatched if higher-priority students never apply. Accepting Student_C now secures a relatively high-priority student within quota 1 and removes uncertainty.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions,

I’m Student_E and I’m writing to formally apply to School_D. After learning that my first-choice option is no longer available, School_D is my top remaining choice because I value the learning environment and would be excited to contribute through consistent effort, respectful collaboration, and strong classroom engagement.

If admitted, I will accept and commit to enrolling at School_D.

Thank you very much for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: School_C (my top choice) has already filled its seat, so I should immediately pursue my next highest remaining option. School_D is my second choice and still unmatched, so applying now maximizes my chance to secure a high-preference match before its seat is taken. I will signal strong commitment to increase acceptance likelihood given School_D’s priority list places me mid-pack.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application to School_D and for sharing your strong interest in our community. At this time, our incoming class is full and we are not able to extend an offer of admission.

If space becomes available later, we will review candidates again and may reach out. We appreciate your time and wish you the very best with your remaining options.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E submitted an [APPLY]. However, School_D’s remaining quota is 0 and we are already matched with Student_C from the prior round. Per the rules, with quota 0 we must reject any new applications regardless of our true priority ordering (where Student_E is ranked below Student_C anyway). Therefore, reject Student_E while offering a waitlist-style note if space opens.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions—I'm Student_A. School_A is one of my top choices, and I’m very interested in joining your community for its strong academics and supportive environment. I would be grateful for the opportunity to enroll and am ready to accept immediately if offered a seat. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_B already rejected me and I am last in School_B’s priority list, so reapplying is very unlikely to succeed. My next true choice is School_C, but it is not available this round. Among available schools, School_A is my third choice and I have relatively strong priority there (3rd), so an application has a realistic chance of acceptance while still aligning with my preferences.

School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_A is 3rd on School_A’s true priority list (behind Student_E and Student_D). With quota 1, accepting Student_A now would forfeit the chance to match with Student_E or Student_D if they apply later. Given Student_E ranks School_A 3rd and Student_D ranks School_A 3rd, they may apply after attempting School_B/School_C first, so holding the seat is strategically valuable. Therefore, reject Student_A’s application now to preserve capacity for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear School_B Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_D, and I’m writing to formally apply for your available seat this round. School_B is my first-choice school because I’m seeking a rigorous academic environment and a community where I can contribute consistently through my coursework and involvement in school activities.

If admitted, I am ready to commit and would be excited to join School_B.

Thank you for your consideration.
Sincerely,
Student_D
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, and it is still available. Based on School_B’s priority list, I am ranked 4th, so acceptance is possible if higher-priority students apply elsewhere. Since I was rejected by School_C last round, I should now apply to my highest remaining option rather than spend a round talking. I will send a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and willingness to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_B. We appreciate your commitment and are pleased to offer you admission for our available seat.

Congratulations—we look forward to welcoming you to School_B.

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_B with one seat, my true priority order is E > B > C > D > A. I already rejected A and C; D is acceptable but lower priority than E and B, who may still apply in later rounds. Given the market, Student_E ranks School_B last so is unlikely to apply; Student_B ranks School_B second and may apply if not accepted by School_A. Holding the seat could allow a higher-priority match, but risks ending unmatched. Since D is a committed first-choice applicant and within my acceptable list, and there is no higher-priority applicant in the inbox this round, accepting secures a match now rather than speculating on B applying later.

conversation.message:
Dear School_A Admissions,

I’m Student_A and I’m writing to re-apply now that the process has progressed. School_A remains one of my top choices because of its strong academics and supportive community. If offered a seat, I’m ready to accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

If you’re reconsidering candidates given current availability, I would be grateful to be considered for the open spot.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_A
conversation.thought: Remaining unmatched schools are School_A and School_E. On my true preference list, School_A (3rd) is preferred over School_E (4th). I previously applied to School_A and was rejected, but it may have been due to competition in that round; since School_A is still unmatched now, there may be an opening and a renewed application could succeed. I will re-apply to School_A, emphasize commitment and fit, and ask to be reconsidered given current availability.

conversation.message:

We appreciate your strong interest in School_A and wish you the very best in the remainder of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: We have 1 seat and no current match. School_A true priority ranks Student_E above Student_A (E > D > A > B > C). In this round, both Student_A and Student_E applied. Since accepting Student_A now would fill our only seat and prevent matching with higher-priority Student_E who is currently applying and willing to commit, we should reject Student_A to preserve the seat for Student_E. Student_A has already been rejected once; consistent with priorities and optimal outcome, reject again.
